lines.value:
Alcestis
By Euripides
Written 438 B.C.E
Translated by Richard Aldington

Dwelling of Admetus, wherein I, a God, deigned to accept the 
food of serfs!
The cause was Zeus. He struck Asclepius, my son, full in the breast 
with a bolt of thunder, and laid him dead. Then in wild rage I slew the 
Cyclopes who forge the fire of Zeus. To atone for this my Father forced 
me to labour as a hireling for a mortal man; and I came to this country, 
and tended oxen for my host. To this hour I have protected him and his. 
I, who am just, chanced on the son of Pheres, a just man, whom I have saved 
from Death by tricking the Fates. The Goddesses pledged me their faith 
Admetus should escape immediate death if, in exchange, another corpse were 
given to the Under-Gods.
One by one he tested all his friends, and even his father and the 
old mother who bad brought him forth-and found none that would die for 
him and never more behold the light of day, save only his wife. Now, her 
spirit waiting to break loose, she droops upon his arm within the house; 
this is the day when she must die and render up her 
life.
But I must leave this Palace's dear roof, for fear pollution soil 
me in the house.
See! Death, Lord of All the Dead, now comes to lead her to the 
house of Hades! Most punctually he comes! How well he marked the day she 
had to die!
lines.speaker: APOLLO

lines.value:
From the right comes DEATH, with a drawn sword in his hand. He moves 
stealthily towards the Palace; then sees APOLLO and halts abruptly. The 
two Deities confront each other.
lines.speaker: APOLLO

lines.value:
Ha! Phoebus! You! Before this Palace! Lawlessly would you grasp, 
abolish the rights of the Lower Gods! Did you not beguile the Fates and 
snatch Admetus from the grave? Does not that suffice? Now, once again, 
you have armed your hand with the bow, to guard the daughter of Pelias 
who must die in her husband's stead!
lines.speaker: DEATH

lines.value: Fear not! I hold for right, and proffer you just words.
lines.speaker: APOLLO

lines.value: If you hold for right, why then your bow?
lines.speaker: DEATH

lines.value: My custom is ever to carry it.
lines.speaker: APOLLO

lines.value: Yes! And you use it unjustly to aid this house!
lines.speaker: DEATH

lines.value: I grieve for a friend's woe.
lines.speaker: APOLLO

lines.value: So you would rob me of a second body?
lines.speaker: DEATH

lines.value: Not by force I won the other.
lines.speaker: APOLLO

lines.value: Why, then, is he in the world and not below the ground?
lines.speaker: DEATH

lines.value: In his stead he gives his wife-whom you have come to take.
lines.speaker: APOLLO

lines.value: And shall take-to the Underworld below the earth!
lines.speaker: DEATH

lines.value: Take her, and go! I know not if I can persuade you...
lines.speaker: APOLLO

lines.value: Not to kill her I must kill? I am appointed to that task.
lines.speaker: DEATH

lines.value: No, no! But to delay death for those about to die.
lines.speaker: APOLLO

lines.value: I hear your words and guess your wish!
lines.speaker: DEATH

lines.value: May not Alcestis live to old age?
lines.speaker: APOLLO

lines.value: No! I also prize my rights!
lines.speaker: DEATH

lines.value: Yet at most you win one life.
lines.speaker: APOLLO

lines.value: They who die young yield me a greater prize.
lines.speaker: DEATH

lines.value: If she dies old, the burial will be richer.
lines.speaker: APOLLO

lines.value: Phoebus, that argument favours the rich.
lines.speaker: DEATH

lines.value: The rich would gladly pay to die old.
lines.speaker: DEATH

lines.value: So you will not grant me this favour?
lines.speaker: APOLLO

lines.value: Not I! You know my nature.
lines.speaker: DEATH

lines.value: Yes! Hateful to men and a horror to the gods!
lines.speaker: APOLLO

lines.value: You cannot always have more than your due.
lines.speaker: DEATH

lines.value:
Yet you shall change, most cruel though you are! For a man 
comes to the dwelling of Pheres, sent by Eurystheus to fetch a horse-drawn 
chariot from the harsh-wintered lands of Thrace; and he shall be a guest 
in the house of Admetus, and by force shall he tear this woman from you. 
Thus shall you gain no thanks from us, and yet you shall do this thing-and 
my hatred be upon you
lines.speaker: APOLLO

lines.value: APOLLO goes out. DEATH gazes after him derisively.
lines.speaker: APOLLO

lines.value:
Talk all you will, you get no more of me! The woman shall go 
down to the dwelling of Hades. Now must I go to consecrate her for the 
sacrifice with this sword; for when once this blade has shorn the victim's 
hair, then he is sacred to the Lower Gods!
lines.speaker: DEATH

lines.value:
DEATH enters the Palace by the open main door. The CHORUS enters from 
the right. They are the Elders or Notables of the city, and, therefore 
move slowly, leaning upon their staffs.
lines.speaker: DEATH

lines.value:
Were she dead
They had not been silent.
lines.speaker: FIRST SEMI-CHORUS

lines.value: She is but a dead body!
lines.speaker: SECOND SEMI-CHORUS

lines.value: Yet she has not departed the house.
lines.speaker: FIRST SEMI-CHORUS

lines.value:
Ah! Let me not boast!
Why do you cling to hope?
lines.speaker: SECOND SEMI-CHORUS

lines.value:
Would Admetus bury her solitary,
Make a grave alone for a wife so dear?
lines.speaker: FIRST SEMI-CHORUS

lines.value:
At the gate I see not
The lustral water from the spring
Which stands at the gates of the dead!
No shorn tress in the portal
Laid in lament for the dead!
The young women beat not their hands!
lines.speaker: CHORUS

lines.value: Yet to-day is the day appointed....
lines.speaker: SECOND SEMI-CHORUS

lines.value: When she must descend under earth
lines.speaker: SECOND SEMI-CHORUS

lines.value:
You have pierced my soul!
You have pierced my mind!
lines.speaker: FIRST SEMI-CHORUS

lines.value:
He that for long
Has been held in esteem
Must weep when the good are destroyed.
lines.speaker: SECOND SEMI-CHORUS

lines.value:
No!
There is no place on earth
To send forth a suppliant ship-
Not to Lycia,
Not to Ammon's waterless shrine-
To save her from death!
The dreadful doom is at hand.
To what laden altar of what God
Shall I turn my steps?
He alone-
If the light yet shone for his eye-
Asclepius, Phoebus's son,
Could have led her back
From the land of shadows,
From the gates of Hades,
For he raised the dead
Ere the Zeus-driven shaft
Slew him with thunder fire....
But now
What hope can I hold for her life?
lines.speaker: CHORUS

lines.value:
From the women's quarters in the left wing of the Palace comes a woman 
in tears. She is not a slave, but one of the personal attendants on the 
Queen.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: You may say she is both alive and dead.
lines.speaker: SERVANT

lines.value: How can the same man be dead and yet behold the light?
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: She gasps, she is on the verge of death.
lines.speaker: SERVANT

lines.value: Ah, unhappy man! For such a husband what loss is such a wife!
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: The King will not know his loss until he suffers it.
lines.speaker: SERVANT

lines.value: Then there is no hope that her life may be saved?
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: Are all things befitting prepared for her?
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: The robes in which her lord will bury her are ready.
lines.speaker: SERVANT

lines.value:
Then let her know that she dies gloriously, the best of women 
beneath the sun by far!
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
How should she not be the best! Who shall deny it? What should 
the best among women be? How better might a woman hold faith to her lord 
than gladly to die for him? This the whole city knows, but you will marvel 
when you hear what she has done within the house. When she knew that the 
last of her days was come she bathed her white body in river water, she 
took garments and gems from her rooms of cedar wood, and clad herself nobly; 
then, standing before the hearth-shrine, she uttered this 
prayer:
'O Goddess, since now I must descend beneath the earth, for the 
last time I make supplication to you: and entreat you to protect my motherless 
children. Wed my son to a fair bride, and my daughter to a noble husband. 
Let not my children die untimely, as I their mother am destroyed, but grant 
that they live out happy lives with good fortune in their own 
land!'
To every altar in Admetus's house she went, hung them with garlands. 
offered prayer, cut myrtle boughs-unweeping, unlamenting; nor did the coming 
doom change the bright colour of her face.
Then to her marriage-room she went, flung herself down upon her 
bed, and wept, and said:
'O my marriage-bed, wherein I loosed my virgin girdle to him for 
whom I die! Farewell! I have no hatred for you. Only me you lose. Because 
I held my faith to you and to my lord-I must die. Another woman shall possess 
you, not more chaste indeed than I, more fortunate perhaps.'
She fell upon her knees and kissed it, and all the bed was damp 
with the, tide of tears which flooded to her eyes. And when she was fulfilled 
of many tears, drooping she rose from her bed and made as if to go, and 
many times she turned to go and many times turned back, and flung herself 
once more upon the bed.
Her children clung to their mother's dress, and wept; and she clasped 
them in her arms and kissed them turn by turn, as a dying 
woman.
All the servants in the house wept with compassion for their Queen, 
But she held out her hand to each, and there was none so base to whom she 
did not speak, and who did not reply again.
Such is the misery in Admetus's house. If he had died, he would 
be nothing now; and, having escaped, he suffers an agony he will never 
forget.
lines.speaker: SERVANT

lines.value:
And does Admetus lament this woe-since he must be robbed of 
so noble a woman?
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
He weeps, and clasps in his arms his dear bedfellow, and cries 
to her not to abandon him, asking impossible things. For she pines, and 
is wasted by sickness. She falls away, a frail burden on his arm; and yet, 
though faintly, she still breathes, still strives to look upon the sunlight, 
which she shall never see hereafter-since now for the last time she looks 
upon the orb and splendour of the sun I
I go, and shall announce that you are here; for all men are not 
so well-minded to their lords as loyally to stand near them in misfortunes, 
but you for long have been a friend to both my lords.
lines.speaker: SERVANT

lines.value:
She goes back into the women's quarters of the Palace. The CHORUS now 
begins to sing.
lines.speaker: SERVANT

lines.value:
O Zeus,
What end to these woes?
What escape from the Fate
Which oppresses our lords?
lines.speaker: FIRST SEMI-CHORUS

lines.value:
Will none come forth?
Must I shear my hair?
Must we wrap ourselves
In black mourning folds?
lines.speaker: SECOND SEMI-CHORUS
FIRST SEMI-CHORUS

lines.value:
O King, O Healer,
Seek out appeasement
To Admetus's agony!
Grant this, Oh, grant it!
Once before did you find it;
Now once more
Be the Releaser from death.
The Restrainer of blood-drenched Hades!
lines.speaker: CHORUS

lines.value:
Alas!
O son of Pheres.
What ills shall you suffer
Being robbed of your spouse!
lines.speaker: SECOND SEMI-CHORUS

lines.value:
At sight of such woes
Shall we cut our throats?
Shall we slip
A dangling noose round our necks?
lines.speaker: FIRST SEMI-CHORUS

lines.value:
See! See!
She comes
From the house with her lord!
Cry out, Oh, lament.
O land of Pherae,
For the best of women
Fades away in her doom
Under the earth,
To dark Hades!
lines.speaker: CHORUS

lines.value:
From the central door of the Palace comes a splendid but tragical procession. 
Preceded by the royal guards, ADMETUS enters, supporting ALCESTIS. The 
two children, a boy and a girl, cling to their mother's dress. There is 
a train of attendants and waiting women, who bring a low throne for the 
fainting ALCESTIS.
lines.speaker: CHORUS

lines.value:
The sun looks upon you and me, both of us miserable, who have 
wrought nothing against the Gods to deserve death.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value:
Rouse up, O unhappy one, and, do not leave me! Call upon the 
mighty Gods to pity!
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: starting up and gazing wildly in terror, chanting
lines.speaker: ALCESTIS

lines.value:
Alas! How bitter to me is that ferrying of which you speak! 
O my unhappy one, how we suffer!
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value:
O piteous to those that love you, above all to me and to these 
children who sorrow in this common grief!
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: She falls back in the throne.
lines.speaker: ALCESTIS

lines.value:
Take heart! I do not hesitate to speak for him. This he will 
do, unless he has lost his senses.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
It shall be so, it shall be! Have no fear! And since I held 
you living as my wife, so, when dead, you only shall be called my wife, 
and in your place no bride of Thessaly shall salute me hers; no other woman 
is noble enough for that, no other indeed so beautiful of face. My children 
shall suffice me; I pray the Gods I may enjoy them, since you we have not 
enjoyed.
I shall wear mourning for you, O my wife, not for one year but 
all my days, abhorring the woman who bore me, hating my father-for they 
loved me in words, not deeds. But you-to save my life you give the dearest 
thing you have! Should I not weep then, losing such a wife as 
you?
I shall make an end of merry drinking parties, and of flower-crowned 
feasts and of the music which possessed my house. Never again shall I touch 
the lyre, never again shall I raise my spirits to sing to the Libyan flute-for 
you have taken from me all my joy. Your image, carven by the skilled hands 
of artists, shall be laid in our marriage-bed; I shall clasp it, and my 
hands shall cling to it and I shall speak your name and so, not having 
you, shall think I have my dear wife in my arms-a cold delight, I know, 
but it will lighten the burden of my days. Often you will gladden me, appearing 
in my dreams; for sweet it is to look on those we love in dreams, however 
brief the night.
Ah! If I had the tongue and song of Orpheus so that I might charm 
Demeter's Daughter or her Lord, and snatch you back from Hades, would go 
down to hell; and neither Pluto's dog nor Charon, Leader of the Dead, should 
hinder me until I had brought your life back to the 
light!
At least await me there whenever I shall die, and prepare the house 
where you will dwell with me. I shall lay a solemn charge upon these children 
to stretch me in the same cedar shroud with you, and lay my side against 
your side; for even in death let me not be separate from you, you who alone 
were faithful to me!
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value:
O my children, you have heard your father say that never will 
he set another wife over you and never thus insult me.
lines.speaker: ALCESTIS

lines.value: Again I say it, and will perform it too!
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: placing the children's hands in his
lines.speaker: ALCESTIS

lines.value: I take them-dear gifts from a dear hand.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: Now you must be the mother for me to my children.
lines.speaker: ALCESTIS

lines.value: It must be so, since they are robbed of you.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value:
O children, I should have lived my life out-and I go to the 
Underworld.
lines.speaker: ALCESTIS

lines.value: Alas! What shall I do, left alone by you?
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: Time will console you. The dead are nothing.
lines.speaker: ALCESTIS

lines.value: Take me with you, by the Gods! Take me to the Underworld!
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: It is enough that I should die-for you.
lines.speaker: ALCESTIS

lines.value: O Fate, what a wife you steal from me!
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: O woman, I am lost if you leave me!
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: You may say of me that I am nothing.
lines.speaker: ALCESTIS

lines.value: Lift up your head! Do not abandon your children!
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: Ah! Indeed it is unwillingly-but, farewell, my children!
lines.speaker: ALCESTIS

lines.value: What are you doing? Are you leaving me?
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: She is gone! The wife of Admetus is no more.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
She hears not, she sees not. You and I are smitten by a dread 
calamity.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value:
Admetus, you must endure this calamity. You are not the first 
and will not be the last to lose a noble wife. We all are doomed to die.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
I know it.
Not unawares did this woe swoop down on me; for long it has gnawed 
at me.
But, since I shall ordain the funeral rites for this dead body, 
you must be there, and meanwhile let a threnody re-echo to the implacable 
God of the Underworld. And all you men of Thessaly whom I rule-I order 
you to share the mourning for this woman with severed hair and black-robed 
garb. You who yoke the four-horsed chariot and the swift single horses, 
cut the mane from their necks with your steel.
Let there be no noise of flutes or lyre within the city until twelve 
moons are fulfilled. Never shall I bury another body so dear to me, never 
one that has loved me better. From me she deserves all honour, since she 
alone would die for me!
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value:
The body of ALCESTIS is carried solemnly into the Palace, followed by 
ADMETUS, With bowed head, holding one of his children by each hand. When 
all have entered, the great doors are quietly shut.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value:
From the left HERACLES enters. He is black-bearded and of great physical 
strength; he wears a lion-skin over his shoulders and carries a large 
club.
lines.speaker: CHORUS

lines.value:
The son of Pheres is in his home, O Heracles. But, tell us, 
what brings you to the land of Thessaly and to the city of Pherae?
lines.speaker: LEADER OF THE CHORUS

lines.value: I have a task I must achieve for Eurystheus of Tiryns.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: Where do you go? To what quest are you yoked?
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: The quest of the four-horsed chariot of Diomedes, the Thracian.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: But how will you achieve it? Do you know this stranger?
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: No, I have never been to the land of the Bistones.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: You cannot obtain the horses without a struggle.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: You must kill to return, or you will remain there dead.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: It will not be the first contest I have risked.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: And if you conquer the King will you gain anything?
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: I shall bring back his foals to the lord of Tiryns.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: It is not easy to thrust the bit into their jaws.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: Only if they breathe fire from their nostrils!
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: But they tear men with their swift jaws.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: You speak of the food of wild mountain beasts, not of horses.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: You may see their mangers foul with blood.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: Of what father does the breeder boast himself the son?
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: Of Ares, the lord of the gold-rich shield of Thrace!
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
In this task once more you remind me of my fate, which is ever 
upon harsh steep ways, since I must join battle with the sons of Ares-first 
with Lycaon, then with Cycnus, and now in this third contest I am come 
to match myself with these steeds and their master!
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value:
But see, the lord of this land, Admetus himself, comes from 
the house!
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
The central doors of the Palace have opened, and ADMETUS comes slowly 
on the Stage, preceded and followed by guards and attendants. The King 
has put off all symbols of royalty, and is dressed in black. His tong hair 
is clipped close to his head. ADMETUS dissembles his grief throughout this 
scene, in obedience to the laws of hospitality, which were particularly 
reverenced in Thessaly.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: Hail Son of Zeus and of the blood of Perseus!
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: And hail to you, Admetus, lord of the Thessalians
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: May it be so! I know your friendship well.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: What means this shorn hair, this mourning robe?
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: To-day I must bury a dead body.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: May a God avert harm from your children!
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: The children I have begotten are alive in the house.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: Your father was ripe for death-if it is he has gone?
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: He lives-and she who brought me forth, O Heracles.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: Do you mean that she is dead or alive?
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: Did you not know the fate which must befall her?
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: I know she submitted to die for you.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: How then can she be alive, having consented to this?
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: Ah! Do not weep for your wife till that time comes.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: Those who are about to die are dead, and the dead are nothing.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: Men hold that to be and not to be are different things.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: You hold for one, Heracles, and I for the other.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: Whom, then, do you mourn? Which of your friends is dead?
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: A woman. We spoke of her just now.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: A stranger, but one related to this house.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: But how, then, did she chance to die in your house?
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: When her father died she was sheltered here.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: Alas! Would I had not found you in this grief, Admetus!
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: What plan are you weaving with those words?
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: I shall go to the hearth of another friend.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: Not so, O King! This wrong must not be.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: But it is shameful to feast among weeping friends.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: We shall put you in the guest-rooms, which are far apart.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: Let me go, and I will give you a thousand thanks.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: No, you shall not go to another man's hearth.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value:
HERACLES enters the Palace by the guests' door; when he has gone in, 
ADMETUS turns to the other servants
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: The attendants go into the Palace.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value:
What are you about? When such a calamity has fallen upon you, 
Admetus, have you the heart to entertain a guest? Are you mad?
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
And if I had driven away a guest who came to my house and city, 
would you have praised me more? No, indeed! My misfortune would have been 
no less, and I inhospitable. One more ill would have been added to those 
I have if my house were called inhospitable. I myself find him the best 
of hosts when I enter the thirsty land of Argos.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value:
But why did you hide from him the fate that has befallen, if 
the man came as a friend, as you say?
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
Never would he have entered my house if he had guessed my 
misfortune.
To some, I know, I shall appear senseless in doing this, and they 
will blame me; but my roof knows not to reject or insult a guest.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value:
He goes into the Palace, as the CHORUS begins its 
song.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value:
The funeral procession of ALCESTIS enters from the door of the women's 
quarters. The body, carried on a bier by men servants, is followed by ADMETUS 
and his two children. Behind them comes a train of attendants and servants 
carrying the funeral offerings. All are in mourning. ADMETUS addresses 
the CHORUS.
lines.speaker: CHORUS

lines.value:
O friendly presence of you men of Pherae! Now that the body 
is prepared, and the servants bear it on high to the tomb and the fire, 
do you, as is fitting, salute the dead as she goes forth on her last journey.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value:
PHERES, the father of ADMETUS, enters, followed by attendants bearing 
funeral offerings.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value:
But I see your father, tottering with an old man's walk, and 
his followers bearing in their hands for your wife garments as an offering 
to the dead.
lines.speaker: LEADER OF THE CHORUS

lines.value:
My son, I have come to share your sorrow, for the wife you 
have lost was indeed noble and virtuous-none can deny it. But these things 
must be endured, however intolerable they may be.
Take these garments, and let her descend under the earth. Her body 
must be honoured, for she died to save your life, my son; she has not made 
me childless, nor left me to be destroyed without you in my hapless old 
age; and she has given glorious fame to all women by daring so noble a 
deed!
lines.speaker: PHERES

lines.value: He lifts his hand in salutation to the body of ALCESTIS.
lines.speaker: PHERES

lines.value:
Admetus! The present misfortune is enough. Do not provoke your 
father's spirit.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
ADMETUS turns angrily to depart, but PHERES prevents 
him.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
My son, do you think you are pursuing some hireling Lydian 
or Phrygian with your taunts? Do you know I am a Thessalian, a free man 
lawfully begotten by a Thessalian father? You are over-insolent, and you 
shall not leave thus, after wounding me with your boyish insults. I indeed 
begot you, and bred you up to be lord of this land, but I am not bound 
to die for you. It is not a law of our ancestors or of Hellas that the 
fathers should die for the children! You were born to live your own life, 
whether miserable or fortunate; and what is due to you from me you have. 
You rule over many men, and I shall leave you many wide fields even as 
received them from my own father. How, then, have I wronged you? Of what 
have I robbed you? Do not die for me, any more than I die for you. You 
love to look upon the light of day-do you think your father hates it? I 
tell myself that we are a long time underground and that life is short, 
but sweet.
But you-you strove shamelessly not to die, and you are alive, you 
shirked your fate by killing her! And you call me a coward, you, the worst 
of cowards, surpassed by a woman who died for you, pretty boy? And now 
you insult those who should be dear to you, when they refuse to die for 
a coward like you!
Be silent! Learn that if you love your life, so do others. If you 
utter insults, you shall hear many, and true ones too!
lines.speaker: PHERES

lines.value:
These insults and those that went before suffice. Old man, 
cease to revile your son.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: I should have wronged you far more if I had died for you.
lines.speaker: PHERES

lines.value:
It is the same then to die an old man and in the flower of 
life?
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: We should live one life, not two.
lines.speaker: PHERES

lines.value: May you live longer than God!
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: Do you curse your parents when they have done you no wrong?
lines.speaker: PHERES

lines.value: I see you are in love with long life.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: But you are not carrying her dead body in place of your own?
lines.speaker: PHERES

lines.value: It is the proof of your cowardice, O worst of men.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: You cannot say she died for me!
lines.speaker: PHERES

lines.value: Alas! May you one day need my help.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: Woo many women, so that more may die for you.
lines.speaker: PHERES

lines.value: To your shame be it-you who dared not die.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: Sweet is the daylight of the Gods, very sweet.
lines.speaker: PHERES

lines.value: Your spirit is mean, not a man's.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: Would you laugh to carry an old man's body to the grave?
lines.speaker: PHERES

lines.value: You will die infamous, whenever you die.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value:
It will matter little enough to me to hear ill of myself when 
I am dead!
lines.speaker: PHERES

lines.value: Alas! Alas! full of impudence. is old age!
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: She was not impudent, but foolish,
lines.speaker: PHERES

lines.value: Go! Leave me to bury her body.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value:
PHERES goes out by the way he entered, followed by his attendants. ADMETUS 
gazes angrily after him.
lines.speaker: PHERES

lines.value:
Go with a curse, you, and she who dwells with you! Grow old, 
as you ought, childless though you have a child. You shall never return 
to this house. And if I could renounce your hearth as my father's by heralds, 
I would do it. But we-since this sorrow must be endured-let us go, and 
set her body on the funeral pyre.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value:
The Procession moves slowly along the stage, and is joined by the CHORUS. 
As they pass, the LEADER salutes the body of ALCESTIS.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value:
The Procession has filed out. A servant in mourning hurries out from 
the guests' quarters.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
Many guests from every land, I know, have come to the Palace 
of Admetus, and I have set food before them, but never one worse than this 
guest have I welcomed to the hearth.
First, though he saw our Lord was in mourning, he entered, and 
dared to pass through the gates. Then, knowing our misfortune, he did not 
soberly accept what was offered him, but if anything was not served to 
him he ordered us to bring it. In both hands he took a cup of ivy-wood, 
and drank the unmixed wine of the dark grape-mother, until he was encompassed 
and heated with the flame of wine. He crowned his head with myrtle sprays, 
howling discordant songs. There was he caring nothing for Admetus's misery, 
and we servants weeping for our Queen; and yet we hid our tear-laden eyes 
from the guest, for so Admetus had commanded.
And now in the Palace I must entertain this stranger, some villainous 
thief and brigand, while she, the Queen I mourn, has gone from the house 
unfollowed, unsaluted, she who was as a mother to me and all us servants, 
for she sheltered us from a myriad troubles by softening her husband's 
wrath.
Am I not right, then, to hate this stranger, who came to us in 
the midst of sorrow?
lines.speaker: SERVANT

lines.value:
HERACLES comes from the Palace. He is drunkenly merry, with a myrtle 
wreath on his head, and a large cup and wine-skin in his hands. He staggers 
a little.
lines.speaker: SERVANT

lines.value:
Hey, you! Why so solemn and anxious? A servant should not be 
sullen with guests, but greet them with a cheerful heart.
You see before you a man who is your lord's friend, and you greet 
him with a gloomy, frowning face, because of your zeal about a strange 
woman's death. Come here, and let me make you a little wiser!
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value:
We know all that, but what we endure here to-day is far indeed 
from gladness and laughter.
lines.speaker: SERVANT

lines.value:
But the dead woman was a stranger. Lament not overmuch, then, 
for the Lords of this Palace are still alive.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: How, alive? Do you not know the misery of this house?
lines.speaker: SERVANT

lines.value: Your lord did not lie to me?
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: He goes too far in hospitality!
lines.speaker: SERVANT

lines.value: But why should I suffer for a stranger's death?
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: It touches this house only too nearly.
lines.speaker: SERVANT

lines.value: Did he hide some misfortune from me?
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: Go in peace! The miseries of our lords concern us.
lines.speaker: SERVANT

lines.value: That speech does not imply mourning for a stranger!
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: No, or I should not have been disgusted to see you drinking.
lines.speaker: SERVANT

lines.value: Have I then been basely treated by my host?
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value:
You did not come to this house at a welcome hour. We are in 
mourning. You see my head is shaved and the black garments I wear.
lines.speaker: SERVANT

lines.value: But who, then, is dead? One of the children? The old father?
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: O stranger, Admetus no longer has a wife.
lines.speaker: SERVANT

lines.value: What! And yet I was received in this way?
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: He was ashamed to send you away from his house.
lines.speaker: SERVANT

lines.value: O hapless one! What a wife you have lost!
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: Not she alone, but all of us are lost.
lines.speaker: SERVANT

lines.value:
Beside the straight road which leads to Larissa you will see 
a tomb of polished stone outside the walls.
lines.speaker: SERVANT

lines.value:
O heart of me, much-enduring heart, O right arm, now indeed 
must you show what son was born to Zeus by Alcmena, the Tirynthian, daughter 
of Electryon! For I must save this dead woman, and bring back Alcestis 
to this house as a grace to Admetus.
I shall watch for Death, the black-robed Lord of the Dead, and 
I know I shall find him near the tomb, drinking the blood of the sacrifices. 
If can leap upon him from an ambush, seize him, grasp him in my arms, no 
power in the world shall tear his bruised sides from me until he has yielded 
up this woman. If I miss my prey, if he does not come near the bleeding 
sacrifice, I will go down to Kore and her lord in their sunless dwelling, 
and I will make my entreaty to them, and I know they will give me Alcestis 
to bring back to the hands of the host who welcomed me, who did not repulse 
me from his house, though he was smitten with heavy woe which most nobly 
he hid from me! Where would be a warmer welcome in Thessaly or in all the 
dwellings of Hellas?
He shall not say he was generous to an ingrate!
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value:
HERACLES goes out. Presently ADMETUS and his attendants, followed by 
the CHORUS, return from the burial of ALCESTIS.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: I know you have entered into sorrow.
lines.speaker: CHORUS

lines.value: Yet you bring no aid to the dead.
lines.speaker: CHORUS

lines.value:
Heavy shall it be for you
Never to look again
On the face of the woman you love.
lines.speaker: CHORUS

lines.value:
You bring to my mind the grief that breaks my heart. What sorrow 
is worse for a man than the loss of such a woman? I would I had never married, 
never shared my house with her. I envy the wifeless and the childless. 
They live but one life-what is suffering to them? But the sickness of children, 
bridal-beds ravished by Death-dreadful! when we might be wifeless and childless 
to the end.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: Chance, dreadful Chance, has stricken you.
lines.speaker: CHORUS

lines.value: But you set no limit to your grief.
lines.speaker: CHORUS

lines.value: A heavy burden to bear, and yet...
lines.speaker: CHORUS

lines.value: Courage! You are not the first to lose...
lines.speaker: CHORUS

lines.value:
A wife.
Different men
Fate crushes with different blows.
lines.speaker: CHORUS

lines.value:
O long grief and mourning for those beloved under the 
earth!
Why did you stay me from casting myself into the hollow grave to lie 
down for ever in death by the best of women? Two lives, not one, had then 
been seized by Hades, most faithful one to the other; and together we should 
have crossed the lake of the Underworld.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value:
A son most worthy of tears
Was lost to one of my house,
Yet, childless, he suffered with courage,
Though the white was thick in his hair
And his days were far-spent!
lines.speaker: CHORUS

lines.value:
O visage of my house! How shall I enter you? How shall I dwell 
in you, now that Fate has turned its face from me? How great is the change! 
Once, of old, I entered my house with marriage-songs and the torches of 
Pelion, holding a loved woman by the hand, followed by a merry crowd shouting 
good wishes to her who is dead and to me, because we had joined our lives, 
being both noble and born of noble lines. Today, in place of marriage-songs 
are lamentations; instead of white garments I am clad in mourning, to return 
to my house and a solitary bed.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value:
Grief has fallen upon you
In the midst of a happy life
Untouched by misfortune.
But your life and your spirit are safe.
She is dead,
She has left your love.
Is this so new?
Ere now many men
Death has severed from wives.
lines.speaker: CHORUS

lines.value:
He covers his head with his robe, and crouches in abject misery on the 
steps of his Palace.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value:
ADMETUS is still crouched on the Palace steps, when HERACLES enters 
from the side, leading a veiled woman.
lines.speaker: CHORUS

lines.value: But see! The son of Alcmena, as I think, comes to your house.
lines.speaker: LEADER OF THE CHORUS

lines.value: ADMETUS uncovers his head, and faces the newcomer.
lines.speaker: LEADER OF THE CHORUS

lines.value:
Admetus, a man should speak freely to his friends, and not 
keep reproaches silent in his heart. Since I was near you in your misfortune, 
should have wished to show myself your friend. But you did not tell me 
the dead body was your wife's, and you took me into your house as if you 
were in mourning only for a stranger. And I put a garland of flowers upon 
my head, and poured wine-offerings to the Gods, when your house was filled 
with lamentation. I blame you, yes, I blame you for this-but I will not 
upbraid you in your misfortune.
Why I turned back and am here, I shall tell you. Take and keep 
this woman for me until I have slain the King of the Bistones and return 
here with the horses of Thrace. If ill happens to me-may I return safely!-I 
give her to you to serve in your house.
With much striving I won her to my hands. On my way I found public 
games, worthy of athletes, and I have brought back this woman whom I won 
as the prize of victory. The winners of the easy tests had horses; heads 
of cattle were given to those who won in boxing and wrestling. Then came 
a woman as a prize. Since I was present, it would have been shameful for 
me to miss this glorious gain. Therefore, as I said, you must take care 
of this woman, whom I bring to you, not as one stolen but as the prize 
of my efforts. Perhaps in time you will approve of what I do.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value:
Not from disdain, nor to treat you as a foe, did I conceal 
my wife's fate from you. But if you had turned aside to another man's hearth, 
one more grief had been added to my sorrow. It was enough that I should 
weep my woe.
This woman-O King, I beg it may be thus-enjoin some other Thessalian, 
one who is not in sorrow, to guard her. In Pherae there are many to welcome 
you. Do not remind me of my grief. Seeing her in my house, I could not 
restrain my tears. Add not a further anguish to my pain, for what I suffer 
is too great. And then-where could I harbour a young woman in my house? 
For she is young-I see by her clothes and jewels. Could she live with the 
men under my roof? How, then, could she remain chaste, if she moved to 
and fro among the young men? Heracles, it is not easy to restrain the young....I 
am thinking of your interests....Must I take her to my dead wife's room? 
How could I endure her to enter that bed? I fear a double reproach-from 
my people, who would accuse me of betraying my saviour to slip into another 
woman's bed, and from my dead wife, who deserves my respect, for which 
I must take care.
O woman, whosoever you may be, you have the form of Alcestis, and 
your body is like hers.
Ah! By all the Gods, take her from my sight! Do not insult a broken 
man. When I look upon her-she seems my wife-my heart is torn asunder-tears 
flow from my eyes. Miserable creature that I am, now taste the bitterness 
of my sorrow.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value:
I do not praise this meeting; but, whatever happens, we must 
accept the gifts of the Gods.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
Oh, that I might bring your wife back into the light of day 
from the dwelling of the Under-Gods, as a gift of grace to you!
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value:
I know you would wish this-but to what end? The dead cannot 
return to the light of day.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: Do not exaggerate, but bear this with decorum.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: Easier to advise than bear the test.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: How will it aid you to lament for ever?
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: I know-but my love whirls me away.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: Love for the dead leads us to tears.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: You have lost a good wife-who denies it?
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: So that for me there is no more pleasure in life.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: Time will heal this open wound.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: You might say Time, if Time were death!
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: Another woman, a new marriage, shall console you.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: Oh, hush! What have you said? A thing unbelievable!
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: What! You will not marry? Your bed will remain widowed?
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: No other woman shall ever lie at my side.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: Do you think that avails the dead?
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: Wherever she may be, I must do her honour.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: I praise you-but men will call you mad.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: Yet never more shall I be called a bridegroom.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: I praise your faithful love to your wife-
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: May I die if I betray her even when dead!
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: offering him the veiled woman's hand.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: No, by Zeus who begot you, no!
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: Yet you will do wrong if you do not take her.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: If I do it, remorse will tear my heart.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: Yield-perhaps it will be a good thing for you.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: Ah! If only you had not won her in the contest!
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: But I conquered-and you conquered with me.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: It is true-but let the woman go hence.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: She shall go, if she must. But first-ought she to go?
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: She must-unless it would anger you.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: There is good reason for my zeal.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: You have conquered then-but not for my pleasure.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: One day you will praise me for it-be persuaded.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: No, I cannot leave such a woman to servants.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: Then lead her in yourself, if you wish.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: I must leave her in your hands.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: I must not touch her-let her go into the house.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: I trust only in your right hand.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: O King, you force me to this against my will.
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: Put forth your hand and take this woman.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: As if you were cutting off a Gorgon's head! Do you hold her?
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value:
Then keep her. You shall not deny that the son of Zeus is a 
grateful guest.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: Takes off the veil and shows ALCESTIS.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: drops her hand and starts back
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: No you look upon your wife indeed.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: Beware! May it not be some phantom from the Underworld?
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: Do not think your guest a sorcerer.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: But do I indeed look upon the wife I buried?
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: Yes-but I do not wonder at your mistrust.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: Can I touch, speak to her, as my living wife?
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: Speak to her-you have all you desired.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: You have her-may the envy of the Gods be averted from you!
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value:
O noble son of greatest Zeus, fortune be yours, and may your 
Father guard you! But how did you bring her back from the Underworld to 
the light of day?
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: By fighting with the spirit who was her master.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value: Then did you contend with Death?
lines.speaker: ADMETUS

lines.value: I hid by the tomb and leaped upon him.
lines.speaker: HERACLES

lines.value:
You may not hear her voice until she is purified from her consecration 
to the Lower Gods, and until the third dawn has risen. Lead her 
in.
And you, Admetus, show as ever a good man's welcome to your 
guests.
Farewell! I go to fu
lines.speaker: HERACLES
